data.title: Madeline, Study of a Nightmare (1974)
data.meta_description: A young woman is tormented by nightmares of her miscarriage. She becomes unfaithful to her husband and meets various lovers. Eventually, reality begins to unfurl around her.
data.text:
Madeline, Study of a Nightmare offers up the pretence of a psychosexual study of reality; realised through the psychedelic lens of 1970s Italy. We open with a dream sequence that sees pregnant Camille Keaton running through the woods while being chased by a bunch of middle aged women in brightly coloured wigs. It's captivating, beautifully shot and feels loaded with some kind of intelligent meaning. It sets the tone nicely for the rest of the film. It's all very lovely to look at. Keaton gets to enjoy herself - driving around in a sports car, taking multiple lovers, skinny dipping snd topless horse riding. The tone is mellow and relaxed. Madeline is a surreal psychological thriller that hasn't got much of a plot. It's about the atmosphere and style. It feels weird because there is no guiding thread in this film. But that doesn't matter because the look and feel of this movie are fantastic. From the outstanding soundtrack to the brilliant cinematography, it had everything I need in a movie.

Camille Keaton delivered a dreamy performance that is strong enough to carry the film. But the supporting cast is pretty cool too, giving us performances by Paola Senatore (Immagini di un convento, Emanuelle in America), Silvano Tranquilli (So Sweet, So Dead, High Crime, and Riccardo Salvino (Your Vice Is a Locked Room and Only I Have the Key).

The 1974 Italian psychosexual horror film, Madeleine: Anatomy of a Nightmare, opens with a dream sequence of the title character, played by Camille Keaton, being chased through a field of tall reeds by spooky witches, each with a different bright florescent hair color. During one camera shot showing the witches from behind, I realized that the backs of their heads look just like the ghosts in the Pac-Man video game, down to the exact same color shades. Once I noticed this, I could not unsee it. After you read this review, you will not be able to unsee it either. You're welcome.

Unfortunately for Madeleine, however, she will never outrun these ghosts. Our unwitting heroine, who is haunted by traumatic‚Ä¶

I kind of liked this film more than most might like it. Some people might find it to be too slow and boring. I get that. I liked the vibe here. It's just kind of a hang.

We get the story of Madeline, a woman who seems to be having issues stemming from her miscarriage. We don't get a lot of details. We get a great opening dream sequence. She's married to a man who loves horses. Unless they aren't married. She picks up a hitchhiker and brings him home for a dip in the pool, both literally and as a euphemism. She gets romantic with her husband's son. Only he doesn't know they are married (and, again, maybe they‚Ä¶

An interesting pick in the Camille Keaton box set, neither a horror, gothic or otherwise, a giallo or a thriller. No, this is a rare film that had less than 40 votes on imdb or letterboxd that may fall into quasi psychedelia, psychosexual art house bleeding its heart out from the inside and then topping itself off with a plot twist. That's funny because a twist in this lackadaisical summer is almost redundant as the narrative.
